questions.text:
During the examination of which of the following swellings would you expect to see transillumination?
  1. Epididymal cyst
  2. Spermatocoele
  3. Ranula
  4. Cystic hygroma
  5. Lipoma
questions.solution:
Epididymal cyst, ranula, spermatocele, and cystic hygroma show transillumination. Lipoma, due to its lipid content not allowing light to pass through, is not transilluminant. 

Transillumination is a technique where a light source is used to shine light through a body part/ swelling to assess the characteristics of the tissue or fluid inside. 

An epididymal cyst is a multilocular cyst formed due to the cystic degeneration of the epididymis. Multiple cysts formed posterior to the epididymis can feel like a bunch of grapes on palpation. Due to the presence of crystal clear fluid, an epididymal cyst brilliantly transilluminates and has a Chinese lantern appearance.


Spermatocele is a unilocular retention cyst formed at the epididymal head. Due to the presence of spermatozoa, barley-water fluid is seen. It shows transillumination.

Ranula is a benign cystic lesion formed by extravasation of mucus, involving the sublingual gland. Clinically present as cystic swelling in the floor of the mouth. On examination, the fluctuation test and transillumination test are positive. It is managed by marsupialization. 

Cystic hygroma is a brilliantly transilluminant cystic swelling containing clear lymph due to the sequestration of a portion of the jugular lymph sac. It usually presents in early infancy or at be present at birth, in which case it may even obstruct labor.

Lipomas present as a painless, slow-growing, soft, and mobile subcutaneous tissue mass. They do not transilluminate. The swelling is non-fluctuant and when palpated, the edge slips under the finger. This is known as the slip sign.

Related Pearl: Brilliantly Transilluminating Swellings

  • Vaginal hydrocele
  • Epididymal cyst
  • Cystic hygroma
  • Ranula
  • Meningocele

questions.text: A 65-year-old trumpet player presents with hoarseness of voice, cough, and neck swelling. The swelling increases in size on coughing and on performing Valsalva maneuver. CT neck is as follows. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of hoarseness of voice, cough, neck swelling that increases in size on coughing/Valsalva maneuver and a gurgling sound heard on pressing the swelling are suggestive of laryngocele. On CT the laryngocele extends both internally and externally, thus labelling this as the combined or mixed subtype.

Laryngocele is an air-filled cystic swelling in the neck due to dilatation of the saccule. It is more commonly seen in trumpet players, glass-blowers, or weight lifters due to a raised transglottic air pressure in these people. It can be classified into internal, external, or combined types of laryngocele.

  • Internal laryngocele is limited within the larynx and appears as distension of the false cord and aryepiglottic fold. CT below shows the presenc e of a right internal laryngocele.
  • External laryngocele has a distended saccule that herniates through the thyrohyoid membrane and appears as a swelling in the neck
  • Combined or mixed laryngocele has both internal and external laryngoceles as its components
    Given below is a diagrammatic representation of laryngocele.


Laryngocele presents with hoarseness of voice, cough, and airway obstruction (if large). External laryngocele presents as a reducible swelling in the neck that increases in size on coughing or performing the Valsalva maneuver. On pressing the neck swelling, a gurgling sound is heard, indicating a positive Bryce's sign. Adult laryngoceles can be associated with carcinoma.

Diagnosis is based on an indirect laryngoscopy and CT scan. Internal laryngocele is managed by marsupialization and external laryngocele is managed by a surgical excision through an external neck incision.

Other options:

Option C- Epiglottic cysts are often benign in nature and tend to manifest on the lingual surface of the epiglottis. The incidence of this phenomenon is infrequent and typically detected in individuals during the acute phase of infection. Typically, patients with epiglottic cysts do not exhibit symptoms, and conservative treatment has traditionally been employed for small-sized cysts. CT below demonstrates the presence of an epiglottic cyst impinging on the right vocal cord.

questions.text: A 5 year old boy is brought by his mother with a swelling on his head as shown below. Clinical examination revealed a 2x2  cm soft, fluctuant, non-tender, non-transilluminant, non-pulsatile swelling with absent central punctum. Palpation of the edge of the swelling yields to your finger. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a soft, fluctuant, non-tender, non-transilluminant, non-pulsatile swelling and an absent central punctum can be diagnosed as a case of dermoid cyst. The presence of a central punctum could tilt the diagnosis to a sebaceous cyst. Lipomas do not yield when pressure is applied to the edge of the swelling (slip sign positive).

A dermoid cyst is a noncancerous skin abnormality that originates from the trapping of ectodermal components during embryonic closure characterized by the presence of stratified squamous epithelium. These tumours also exhibit mature skin appendages on their walls, and their lumens are packed with keratin and hair. Dermoid cysts are widely acknowledged as being congenital in nature; nonetheless, it is worth noting that not all instances of this condition are identified and diagnosed immediately after birth. Dermoid cysts predominantly manifest on the craniofacial region, with a substantial majority of 84% of these cysts being observed in this anatomical area. 

Dermoid cysts present as firm painless subcutaneous nodules and are of 4 types:

  • Sequestration dermoid - sequestration of epithelium during embryological development
  • Tubulodermoid - accumulation of secretions from ectodermal tube/duct
  • Implantation dermoid - implantation of the epidermis due to trauma
  • Teratomatous dermoid - having all 3 germ layers (ecto, meso, and endoderm)

Other options

Option A: Meningoceles are uncommon at the location as shown in the image above. Meningocele also appears as soft to firm swellings which are transilluminant. The image below shows the presence of a meningocele in the cervical area.


Option C: Lipomas present as a painless, slow-growing, soft, and mobile subcutaneous tissue mass. They do not transilluminate. The swelling is non-fluctuant and when palpated, the edge slips under the finger. This is known as the slip sign.


Option D: A sebaceous cyst is a benign swelling that is mobile, fluctuant, and fixed to the skin. It presents with a central punctum in about 70% of cases.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl presents with swelling over her gluteal region as shown below. On each occasion when she is brought to the primary care physician, aspiration of the cyst results in the extraction of transparent fluid, with reappearance after a few weeks to months. Examination reveals a soft, compressible swelling that is brilliantly transilluminant. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's swelling across her sacral area, along with repeated aspirates generating clear fluid and brilliant transillumination, is consistent with meningocele. 

Meningocele is the herniation of meninges through a weak spot of the spine when bone fusion has not taken place adequately. The swelling is enveloped by the pia mater and arachnoid mater, lacking a dural coating, and contains cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). It is most commonly found in the lumbosacral region with occipitocervical location being the second most commonest.

  Meningocele Meningomyelocele
Consistency Soft and cystic  Soft/ Firm
Neurological deficit Absent  Present
Transillumination test Positive Negative
Prognosis after repair Good  Not favourable


Spina bifida is a general term used for neural tube defects affecting the spinal region and associated with splitting of the vertebral arches. It is characterized by gaps in the vertebral arches and may or may not involve the underlying neural tissue.

The illustration shown below shows spina bifida.


The 3 main types of spina bifida:

  • Spina bifida occulta - This is the mildest form of spina bifida. The defect in the vertebral arches is covered by the skin. The splits in the vertebrae are so small that the spinal cord does not protrude. The skin at the site of the lesion may be normal, or it may have some hair growing from it.
  • Meningocele - The defect in the vertebra allows the meninges to protrude through the defect.
  • Myelomeningocele (meningomyelocele) - Defect in the vertebral column allows the spinal cord with the meningeal coverings to protrude. 

The image given below shows the different types of spina bifida.


Other options:

Option A: Lipomas present as a painless, slow-growing, soft, and mobile subcutaneous tissue mass. They do not transilluminate. The swelling is non-fluctuant and when palpated, the edge slips under the finger. This is known as the slip sign. 

Option B: Meningomyelocele is non-transilluminant (according to SRB  Manual of surgery, 6th edition) but there have been reports suggesting that Meningomyelocele can be transilluminant with visualisation of nervous tissue within the sac. 

Option C: Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common soft tissue sarcoma of childhood usually in the head and neck region, most common primary orbital malignancy in children. They are malignant tumours arising from voluntary muscle and produce a rapidly increasing proptosis. It extends in all directions. Diagnosis is done using biopsy in which cross-striations in the tumor cells are pathognomonic. Myoglobulin is a specific marker but it can also be positive for desmin. Transillumination test is negative in patients with rhabdomyosarcoma with a solid aspirate.

questions.text: A 45-year-old comes to you with a swelling over her wrist as shown below. She does not complain of any pain or sudden increase in the size of the swelling. Examination reveals firm, fluctuant,transilluminant mass. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the aforementioned findings?
questions.solution:
This patient's cyst on the dorsum of the hand which is firm, fluctuant and transilluminant is suggestive of a diagnosis of ganglion cyst. 

A diagnosis of ganglion cyst was made because of its location (dorsum of the hand is very common)  and because lipoma, dermoid and sebaceous cyst are not transilluminant.

Ganglion cyst is a swelling that might manifest in association with a tendon sheath, synovial sheath, or joint capsule. The substance contained within it is comprised of a transparent, gelatinous fluid. The precise aetiology of ganglion cyst formation remains uncertain; nevertheless, it is hypothesized that they originate from recurrent microtrauma, leading to mucinous degeneration of connective tissue. Soft tissue masses are frequently observed in the dorsum of the hand and wrist, making them the most prevalent in these regions. However, they are also frequently encountered in the knee and foot. While the majority of ganglion cysts do not exhibit symptoms, patients may experience discomfort, tenderness, and express unhappiness with the cyst's visual appearance. Both aspiration and surgical excision are viable options to be considered. It is imperative to ensure that patients are adequately educated about the potential for recurrence. 

Other options:

Option A: Prevalence of implantation dermoid is frequently observed in the digits of the hand (particularly among tailors and gardeners) following trauma. The occurrence of swelling is typically devoid of discomfort and is commonly noticed subsequent to small trauma, exhibiting a gradual progression primarily in the digits of the hands or feet. The observed lesion exhibits characteristics of smoothness, softness, mobility, tensile cystic structure, lack of transillumination, and frequent adherence to the skin. The lesion comprises of squamous epithelial cells, devoid of hair follicles, sweat glands, or sebaceous glands. 


Option B: A sebaceous cyst is a benign swelling that is mobile, fluctuant, and fixed to the skin. It presents with a central punctum in about 70% of cases. 


Option C: Lipomas present as a painless, slow-growing, soft, and mobile subcutaneous tissue mass. They do not transilluminate. The swelling is non-fluctuant and when palpated, the edge slips under the finger. This is known as the slip sign.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of inability to extend her 4th and 5th digits. Later, she noticed several painless nodules on her palms and her fingers becoming stiffer over time. On examination, the following findings were found. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical features and image suggest the diagnosis of Dupuytren's contracture.

The main causes of this condition include:
  • trauma of chronic repetitive nature
  • heredity (Autosomal dominant)
  • epileptics receiving phenytoin therapy
  • associations with diabetes, epilepsy, smoking, alcoholic cirrhosis, AIDS, and pulmonary tuberculosis
  • occupational causes such as vibrations of machines
Dupuytren's contracture is a proliferating fibroplasia of the subcutaneous palmar tissue, forming nodules of cords along its ulnar border. It results in finger contractures, thinning of subcutaneous fat, pitting of skin and knuckle pads. It is more common in males than females. The prevalence increases with age, but onset at an early stage usually means aggressive disease.
 
Clinical features:

The patient complains of a nodular thickening in the palm or finger. The palm of the ring finger and the PIP of the little finger are the most commonly involved. Initially, the lesion is painless, later it may result in slight tenderness. Often both hands are involved. Gradually the nodules may thicken and contract, forming cords. If the subcutaneous cords extend into the fingers, they may produce flexion deformities at the MCP and PIP joints. Sometimes the dorsal knuckle pads are thickened, known as Garrod’s pads.

Treatment of Dupuytren Disease - 

Nonoperative Operative
External beam radiation 1.Subcutaneous fasciotomy
Steroid injection 2.Partial (selective) fasciectomy
Collagenase 3.Complete fasciectomy
  4.Fasciectomy with skin grafting
  5.Staged external fixation
  6.Arthrodesis
  7.Amputation

Z-plasty is used for the lengthening of linear scars. It is best used in releasing simple contractures. The image below shows Z-plasty:

Other options:

Option A: Prevalence of implantation dermoid is frequently observed in the digits of the hand (particularly among tailors and gardeners) following trauma. The occurrence of swelling is typically devoid of discomfort and is commonly noticed subsequent to small trauma, exhibiting a gradual progression primarily in the digits of the hands or feet. The observed lesion exhibits characteristics of smoothness, softness, mobility, tensile cystic structure, lack of transillumination, and frequent adherence to the skin. The lesion comprises of squamous epithelial cells, devoid of hair follicles, sweat glands, or sebaceous glands. 


Option C: Osler's nodes are painful raised violaceous lesions commonly affecting the fingers, toes, and feet. It is immunologically mediated. The presence of this is suggestive of subacute infective endocarditis (SABE).


Option D: Ganglion cyst is a swelling that might manifest in association with a tendon sheath, synovial sheath, or joint capsule more commonly on the dorsum of the hand. The substance contained within it is comprised of a transparent, gelatinous fluid. The precise aetiology of ganglion cyst formation remains uncertain; nevertheless, it is hypothesized that they originate from recurrent microtrauma, leading to mucinous degeneration of connective tissue.

questions.text: A 40-year-old tailor comes to you with swelling on the palm of his hand from an injury he sustained two years ago while sewing. The swelling is non-transilluminant with no pain, fever, or discharge associated with the swelling. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's cyst on the palmar aspect of the hand with non-transilluminancy following trauma during sewing is suggestive of a diagnosis of implantation dermoid.

A diagnosis of implantation dermoid was made because of an increased occurrence of the lesion following trauma (common among farmers, tailors) as well as its non-transluminant nature. Ganglion cysts are usually transilluminant which more commonly occur on the dorsum of the hand.

Implantation dermoid is frequently observed in the digits of the hand (particularly among tailors and gardeners) following trauma. The occurrence of swelling is typically devoid of discomfort and is commonly noticed subsequent to small trauma, exhibiting a gradual progression primarily in the digits of the hands or feet. The observed lesion exhibits characteristics of smoothness, softness, mobility, tensile cystic structure, lack of transillumination, and frequent adherence to the skin. The lesion comprises of squamous epithelial cells, devoid of hair follicles, sweat glands, or sebaceous glands. 

Complications of implantation dermoid include infection, cyst rupture as well as pressure effect over the digital nerves. Other close differentials of this swelling include lipoma and bursa. Treatment includes surgical excision of the dermoid with local anaesthesia.

Other options

Option A: Ganglion cyst is a swelling that might manifest in association with a tendon sheath, synovial sheath, or joint capsule. The substance contained within it is comprised of a transparent, gelatinous fluid. The precise aetiology of ganglion cyst formation remains uncertain; nevertheless, it is hypothesized that they originate from recurrent microtrauma, leading to mucinous degeneration of connective tissue. Soft tissue masses are frequently observed in the dorsum of the hand and wrist, making them the most prevalent in these regions. 


Option B: A sebaceous cyst is a benign swelling that is mobile, fluctuant, and fixed to the skin. It presents with a central punctum in about 70% of cases. 


Option C: Lipomas present as a painless, slow-growing, soft, and mobile subcutaneous tissue mass. They do not transilluminate. The swelling is non-fluctuant and when palpated, the edge slips under the finger. This is known as the slip sign.

questions.text: A male patient presents with a diffuse swelling over the abdomen as shown in the image below. The swelling is warm,  pits on pressure and is associated with fever. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's lesion on the abdomen is poorly defined with associated warmth, fever and edema (pits on pressure) which is consistent with cellulitis. 

Cellulitis is a painful, diffuse infection of the dermis and the subcutaneous tissue. It is characterized by poorly demarcated areas of marked edema, dilated superficial capillaries, and extravasation of red blood cells and inflammatory cells into the dermis. It is most commonly caused by beta-haemolytic Streptococci, Staphylococci, and Clostridium perfringens. The point of entry may be a traumatic or surgical wound.

Lower limbs are the commonest site of cellulitis and any wound, including tinea pedis or bacterial infection, is a possible site of entry. The face is the next common site of infection.

Clinical features include:

  • Constitutional symptoms like fever and malaise
  • Local symptoms like erythema, heat, swelling, and tenderness

Parenteral penicillin is the treatment of choice. Other regimens may include antistaphylococcal penicillins, cefazolin, ceftaroline, and ceftriaxone.

Erysipelas (St.Anthony's fire) Cellulitis
Infection of superficial dermal lymphatics Suppurative inflammation involving the subcutaneous tissue
Raised and sharply demarcated edge that spreads by peripheral extension Diffuse, ill-defined margins
Blistering is common with superficial hemorrhage  Severe cellulitis may show bullae and progress to dermal necrosis
Extends over the ear Does not extend over the ear

Other options:

Option A: Erysipelas is an infection of the superficial epidermis. It presents as an erythematous raised lesion with sharply demarcated edges that differentiate it from the surrounding skin. The given image shows erysipelas.


Option B: Lipomas present as a painless, slow-growing, soft, and mobile subcutaneous tissue mass. They do not transilluminate. The swelling is non-fluctuant and when palpated, the edge slips under the finger. This is known as the slip sign.


Option D: Mesenteric cysts most commonly present as a painless abdominal swelling with a fluctuant swelling near the umbilicus, a swelling moves freely in a plane at right angles to the attachment of the mesentery and the presence of zone of resonance around the cyst(Tillaux triad).

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a swelling on his finger as shown below. The swelling bleeds on touch and does not demonstrate any correlation with pain, regardless of exposure to cold stimuli. These clinical findings are most consistent with a diagnosis of?
questions.solution:
A painless swelling which has the tendency to bleed on touch without correlation to temperature is suggestive of a diagnosis of pyogenic granuloma. Glomus tumors on the other hand exhibit an increase in pain in response to cold stimuli. 

Pyogenic granulomas are capillary hemangiomas that appear as red pedunculated lesions on the skin, gingival, or oral mucosa. They are most commonly benign. They tend to grow rapidly, bleed easily and are often ulcerated. The term pyogenic granuloma is a misnomer as it neither contains pus nor is it a granulomatous lesion. The potential cause could be attributed to a minor traumatic event.

Histologic image of pyogenic granuloma:


It can be managed by surgical excision of the lesion or laser surgery with a minimal margin.

Other options:

Option B: Glomus tumours are seen in adults at 30-40 years of age. Multiple tumours are more common in children than adults and can occur in the hands, head, neck, penis or internal organs. It presents as a pink or purple nodule. Pain is the predominant feature, especially in nail tumours. It is provoked by temperature change and direct pressure. On examination, a bluish-red hue is seen in the following image. Surgical excision is curative as recurrence is rare.


Option C: Implantation dermoids are frequently observed in the digits of the hand (particularly among tailors and gardeners) following trauma. The occurrence of swelling is typically devoid of discomfort and is commonly noticed subsequent to small trauma, exhibiting a gradual progression primarily in the digits of the hands or feet. The observed lesion exhibits characteristics of smoothness, softness, mobility, tensile cystic structure, lack of transillumination, and frequent adherence to the skin. The lesion is not associated with bleeding following touch.


Option D: Koenen tumours or periungual fibromas are strongly suggestive of tuberous sclerosis. These are small fibromas or nodules of skin around fingernails or toenails. Tuberous sclerosis is a multisystem disorder that has an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance (patients would present a lot earlier).

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a swelling as shown in the image which can be moved horizontally but not vertically. Also, fingers were raised but not separated when placed on the surface of the tumor. Based on the above clinical findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a tumour on the lateral side of her neck which does not permit vertical movement but only horizontal movement as well as transmitted pulsation is most likely a carotid body tumour.

The pulsatile swellings, which originate from the arteries, include aneurysms and vascular growths like carotid body tumours. The pulsations of the swellings, which are located in close proximity to the artery and lie superficially to it, can be observed. The phenomenon referred to as transmitted pulsation is distinguished from expansile pulsation, which is generated by the artery walls. Expansile swellings would not only lift the finger but also separate the fingers whereas transmitted pulsations only lift the fingers but do not separate them.

Carotid body tumour:

  • It arises from the chemoreceptor cells in the carotid body, hence called chemodectoma.
  • Mostly presents after 40 years.
  • It is a very slow-growing tumour.

Features:

  • Painless swelling which is pulsatile.
  • Bruit can be heard with a stethoscope.
  • It moves from side to side but not vertically.
  • It may extend into the parapharyngeal space and present in the oropharynx.
  • Some tumours are functional and secrete catecholamines.

Contrast-enhanced CT and MRI with gadolinium are diagnostic and also show the extent of the tumour. MRI angiography shows splaying of internal and external carotid arteries (Lyre’s sign). Serum catecholamines and urinary meta-nephrines and vanillyl mandelic acid (VMA) should be estimated.

Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) or biopsy should not be done because of the vascularity of tumour.

MRI angiography below shows splaying of internal and external carotid arteries - Lyre’s sign


Other options:

Option A: Neurofibroma is a benign tumour arising from the connective tissue of the nerve containing ectodermal, neural and mesodermal connective tissue components. It can be single or multiple. It is the most common intradural extramedullary spinal tumour. Neurofibromas can be local, generalized (von Recklinghausen's disease) or plexiform types. Patients present with mild pain or a painless swelling usually in the subcutaneous or cutaneous plane with tingling, numbness and paraesthesia along the distribution of the nerve.  They do not exhibit transmitted pulsations. 

Option B: A lipoma is a soft painless swelling. It shows the characteristic slip sign and is freely mobile. They do not exhibit transmitted pulsations. 

Option C: Laryngocele is an air-filled cystic swelling due to dilatation of the saccule. External laryngocele presents as a reducible swelling in the neck which increases in size on coughing or performing the Valsalva maneuver. They do not exhibit transmitted pulsations.

questions.text: An elderly man presents with bilateral lower limb swelling which has gradually progressed over the years to present size as shown in the image below. The patient lives in a highland tribal community that continues the practice of walking barefoot. Filarial antigen test is negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient who walks barefoot and lives in a hilly area can be identified as a potential case of Podoconiosis based on a negative filarial antigen test.

Podoconiosis mainly affects people who do not maintain the hygiene of the foot and who stay in hilly regions close to volcanic sites which are rich in irritant red clay soil which leads to absorption of the silica particles in the volcanic rock.

Podoconiosis, often known as "dust in the feet," causes bilateral asymmetrical lower extremity edema. This tropical lymphedema resembles lymphatic filariasis. Podoconiosis, commonly known as endemic non-filarial elephantiasis or "mossy foot," is a non-infectious ailment caused by prolonged barefoot contact with volcanic red clay soil, an irritant. The exact cause of this debilitating condition is unknown, however transdermal migration of silica and aluminium silicate microparticles may cause an abnormal inflammatory response. The particles are absorbed by lymphatic system macrophages, causing an inflammatory response that leads to fibrosis and channel obstruction.

The disease progresses through prodromal, early, and late stages. Forefoot pruritus, burning in the foot and lower leg, fluctuating chills, and generalized arthralgia define the prodromal phase. The symptoms above may progress to forefoot swelling, splaying, and clear lymph fluid leakage. The epidermis forms hyperkeratotic papillomata that resemble moss or velvet, hence the name "mossy foot" in African vernacular. Acute episodes may include fever, rigors, and fast leg discomfort and edema. In the advanced stage, both lower legs may acquire hard, fibrotic edema, with one leg usually worse. Podoconiosis is more common in Ethiopia and widespread in tropical Africa, Central and South America, Indonesia and northwestern parts of India. 

Other options

Option A: Lymphatic filariasis is caused by Wuchereria bancrofti and Brugia malayi. Elephantiasis is a delayed sequel to repeated lymphangitis, obstruction, and lymphedema. Repeated leakage of lymph into tissues first results in lymphedema, then to elephantiasis. A negative filarial antigen test makes this diagnosis unlikely.


Option B: Milroy disease which is the familial version of congenital lymphedema. It is inherited as a dominant trait and is more common before the age of 2 years. 


Option D: Mycetoma is a chronic, granulomatous infection of the skin, subcutaneous tissues, fascia, and bone which most often affects the foot or the hand. It is, therefore, commonly known as Maduramycosis or Madura foot. It can be caused by fungi in which case it is called eumycetoma. Madurella mycetomatis is the most common fungal causative agent. Species of Actinomadura and Nocardia belonging to actinomyces can also cause mycetoma in which case it is referred to as actinomycetoma. The absence of draining sinuses makes this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the pediatrician for the evaluation of a neck mass. On examination, a painless, soft, fluctuating mass is found on the posterior triangle of the neck, as shown in the image below. The slip sign is negative and the swelling is brilliantly transilluminant. Which of the following is not a treatment option for this child?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing mass in the posterior triangle of the neck which is fluctuant and brightly transilluminant is suggestive of cystic hygroma. Sistrunk operation is not a treatment option for cystic hygroma. It is the surgery done for a thyroglossal cyst and limb reduction surgeries in patients with lymphedema.

Cystic hygroma/cavernous lymphangioma is a lymph filled sac that results from the obstruction of the lymph vessels during their development.

Clinically, it presents as a mass in the posterior triangle of the neck. The mass may be apparent at birth or may appear in early childhood due to the increased accumulation of lymph. On examination, it appears as a soft, fluctuating, and brilliantly transilluminant since the sac is filled with lymph.

Complications of cystic hygroma include respiratory difficulty, secondary infection, and chylothorax.

Management:

  • Primarily, the treatment includes aspiration (Option B) of the contents. Later once the sac or capsule gets thickened by fibrous tissue, it is excised.
  • Single cysts are treated with sclerosing therapy (Option C). Commonly used sclerosants include OK– 432 which is an inactive strain of group A Streptococcus pyogenes, pure ethanol, interferon α 2a, and doxycycline.
  • Multiple cysts are treated by complete excision of the cyst (Option D).

questions.text:
Which of the following swellings can move with deglutition?
  1. Thyroglossal cyst
  2. Dermoid cyst
  3. Paratracheal lymph node enlargement
  4. Subhyoid bursitis
questions.solution:
The swellings that move with deglutition include:

  • Thyroglossal cyst
  • Dermoid cyst (if attached to the hyoid)
  • Pre or Paratracheal lymph node enlargement
  • Subhyoid bursitis

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient presented with a scrotal swelling. On examination, the testis is felt separate from the scrotal swelling and the swelling is brilliantly transilluminant, as shown in the image below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a transilluminant scrotal swelling palpated apart from normal testes is suggestive of an epididymal cyst. 

An epididymal cyst is a multilocular cyst formed due to is the cystic degeneration of the epididymis. Multiple cysts formed posterior to the epididymis can feel like a bunch of grapes on palpation. Due to the presence of crystal clear fluid, an epididymal cyst brilliantly transilluminates and has a Chinese lantern appearance.

The image shows the Chinese lantern appearance on transillumination:


It can be differentiated from a hydrocele, where the testis is not separately palpable.

Option A: Varicoceles present with dragging discomfort in the scrotum on standing and characteristic ‘bag of worms’ feel on palpation. 

Option C: Spermatocele is a unilocular transluminant retention cyst formed at the epididymal head. Due to the presence of spermatozoa, barley-water fluid is seen. Although transilluminant, the cyst does not have a Chinese lantern appearance.

Option D: Chyloceles are formed due to the rupture of lymphatic varix and the discharge of chyle into the hydrocele. Fluid rich in cholesterol is seen and the swelling is not transilluminant.

Related Pearl: Brilliantly Transilluminating Swellings

  • Vaginal hydrocele
  • Epididymal cyst
  • Cystic hygroma
  • Ranula
  • Meningocele

questions.text: A young boy who is a known case of Klinefelter's syndrome presents with a painless scrotal swelling and precocious puberty. After an initial ultrasound that revealed a testicular mass, surgical removal was done. The specimen was sent for histopathological analysis; the findings are shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with the biopsy findings points towards the diagnosis of a Leydig cell tumor.

Development of a painless testicular mass in a child with a history of Kleinfelter's syndrome and precocious puberty is suggestive of an androgen-secreting tumor like Leydig cell tumor. The biopsy shows large polygonal cells with a round to oval nucleus and deeply acidophilic with granular cytoplasm. The cytoplasm also shows rod-shaped crystals referred to as "crystalloids of Reinke" which confirms the diagnosis.

Leydig cell tumors are sex-cord stromal cell tumors of the testis. They predominantly secrete androgens and in some cases estrogen and corticosteroids as well. The most common presenting features in prepubertal children are painless testicular swelling and precocious puberty. Leydig-cell tumors are associated with:

  • Kleinfelter's syndrome
  • Cryptorchidism
  • Hereditary leiomyomatosis
  • Renal cell carcinoma syndrome caused by germline mutations in the enzyme fumarate hydratase.

It appears as a homogenous golden-brown tumor, that is usually less than 5cm. On microscopy, round or polygonal cells with a round to oval nucleus and deeply acidophilic with granular cytoplasm are seen. In about 25% of the patients, the cytoplasm contains crystalloids of Reinke as shown below:


Other options:

Option B - Sertoli cell tumors are sex-cord stromal cell tumors of the testis. They are usually hormonally inactive and present only as a painless testicular mass. It is associated with Carneys complex, Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, and familial adenomatosis polyposis syndrome. On microscopy, tumor cells are arranged in trabaculae to form cord-like structures and tubules as shown below:


Option C - Yolk-sac tumor is a non-seminomatous germ cell tumor of the testis also known as endodermal sinus tumor. They secrete α-fetoprotein. On microscopy, a typical lace-like network of medium-sized cuboidal, flattened, or spindled cells, is seen. In half the cases, a mesodermal core with a central capillary and a visceral and parietal layer of cells is present known as Schiller-Duval bodies as shown below:


Option D - Seminoma testis is the most common germ cell tumor. They present as large bulky tumors, without any hemorrhage or necrosis. On microscopy, seminoma cells are round to polyhedral and have a distinct cell membrane, clear or watery-appearing cytoplasm, and a large, central nucleus with one or two prominent nucleoli as shown below:

questions.text: While going through the case sheets of patients admitted to the surgery ward during your internship, you noticed thyroid FNAC of patient A and patient B were reported as Thy 2 and Thy 4 respectively based on the Royal College of Pathologists classification. How would you interpret these FNAC reports?

choices.text: Thyroid swelling in patient A is non-diagnostic (cystic) and patient B's is suspicious of malignancy
Thyroid swelling in patient A is follicular and patient B's is malignant
Thyroid swelling in patient A is non-neoplastic and patient B's is follicular
Thyroid swelling in patient A is non-neoplastic and patient B's is suspicious of malignancy

questions.solution:
Thy 2 in FNAC corresponds to Non-neoplastic lesions and Thy 4 would correspond to suspicion of malignancy.

FNAC has excellent patient compliance. It is simple and quick to perform. 

Classification of fine-needle aspiration cytology reports according to the Royal College of Pathologists,

Type Meaning
Thy 1 Non diagnostic
Thy 1c Non diagnostic cystic
Thy 2 Non neoplastic
Thy 3 Follicular
Thy 4 Suspicious of malignancy
Thy 5 Malignancy 

 

Note: There are 3 major internationally accepted systems for reporting thyroid FNAC results namely the Bethesda system, Royal college of Pathologists and Italian classification. Recently, efforts have been made to create one standardised reporting system.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presented with painless swelling as shown below. On examination, the swelling is soft, cystic, and transillumination positive. Which of the following is false regarding the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: The swelling arises from remnants of 2nd branchial cleft
The cystic swelling is lined by squamous epithelium
FNAC from the swelling may show cholesterol crystals

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of the branchial cyst. It lies superficial to the hypoglossal and glossopharyngeal nerves but deep to the posterior belly of the digastric.

The branchial cyst arises from the remnants of the 2nd branchial cleft. Normally, 2nd, 3rd, and 4th clefts disappear to form a smooth neck. A persistent second cleft is called cervical sinus (of His) which eventually gets sequestered to form a branchial cyst.

Swelling in the neck beneath the anterior border of the upper third of the sternomastoid muscle. It is smooth, soft, fluctuant, and often transilluminate. Even though congenital, it is seen in late adolescents and early 3rd decade.

Histologically, it is lined by squamous epithelium. The cyst wall shows plenty of lymphoid tissue. It may get infected to form an abscess.

FNAC shows cholesterol crystals which are derived from the sebaceous glands in the lining mucous membrane.

Treatment is by complete excision, which is best undertaken when the lesion is quiescent. It passes superficial to the hypoglossal and glossopharyngeal nerves but deep to the posterior belly of the digastric. These structures and the spinal accessory nerve must be positively identified to avoid damage.

Related Pearl: Brilliantly Transilluminating Swellings

  • Vaginal hydrocele
  • Epididymal cyst
  • Cystic hygroma
  • Ranula
  • Meningocele

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presents to the OPD with odynophagia and swelling. He is diagnosed with Ludwig’s angina. How might you describe the swelling?

choices.text: Tender fluctuant swelling in the floor of mouth
Tender fluctuant swelling in the parotid region
Woody hard swelling in the floor of mouth
Woody hard swelling in the parotid region

questions.solution:
Ludwig's angina presents as a tender woody hard swelling on the floor of the mouth.

There can be marked difficulty in swallowing (odynophagia) with varying degrees of trismus. The tongue is progressively pushed upwards and backward, threatening the airway. Laryngeal edema may also be present.

Usually, there is cellulitis of the tissues rather than frank abscess. Incision and drainage show salted pork appearance.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents with swelling in the lower part of the thigh.  During the night, he has severe pain in the region of the swelling, and the pain reduces after taking aspirin. The x-ray is shown below.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the x-ray showing a peripheral sclerotic rim with central radiolucent nidus, is suggestive of osteoid osteoma.

Osteoid osteoma is a benign neoplasm, most often seen in men in the second to third decade of life. In most cases, the lesion appears in the lower extremities, commonly in the femur and tibia. A patient typically presents with pain that worsens at night and is relieved by taking NSAIDs.

Radiography shows a sclerotic peripheral rim with central radiolucent nidus. CT scan can be used to identify the nidus and confirm the diagnosis.

Anti-inflammatory medication can be used for long-term medical management. Percutaneous radiofrequency ablation can be used as an outpatient procedure. Removal of the entire nidus can be done by curettage or en-bloc resection.


Other options:

Option A - Ewing's sarcoma is a malignant bone tumor occurring mainly in the diaphysis of long bones. On x-ray, cortical destruction, and new bone formation in layers are seen, giving the typical onion-peel appearance, as shown below.


Option B- Chondroblastoma is a benign cartilaginous tumor that occurs mainly in bones around the knee joint. On x-ray, the tumor appears as a well-circumscribed, round, or oval lytic lesion in the center of the epiphysis of long bones, with areas of calcification within the tumor, giving the characteristic mottled appearance.

The image below shows an x-ray with a well-circumscribed, round, lytic lesion in the center of the epiphysis of the tibia, which is suggestive of chondroblastoma:


Option D - Osteoblastoma is a benign bone tumor occurring mainly in the spine. Symptoms are similar to those of osteoid osteoma. On X-ray, a radioopaque central nidus with a surrounding radiolucent halo is seen.

The image below shows an osteoblastoma in the C7 vertebra:

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents with a midline neck swelling that moves with deglutition. The histopathology image of the swelling is given below. Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: It is associated with RET mutations
Foci of lymphatic invasion may be present
Associated with a history of exposure to ionising radiation
Metastatic calcification bodies are considered a hallmark microscopic feature

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image showing papillae lined by cells with overlapping nuclei and Orphan Annie eye nuclei indicate a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma of thyroid (PTC). One of the microscopic hallmarks of PTC is psammoma bodies, which are an example of dystrophic calcification, not metastatic calcificaiton.

Papillary carcinoma of thyroid (PTC) presents as a painless nodule or mass in the neck or enlargement of cervical lymph nodes. It usually occurs in women between 25 to 50 years of age. PTC is the most common thyroid cancer associated with previous exposure to ionizing radiation. Conventional PTCs have translocations involving RET or NTRK, and point mutations involving BRAF gene.

On microscopy, branching papillae with fibrovascular stalk covered with multiple layers of anaplastic cuboidal epithelial cells are seen. Because of fine dispersion of the chromatin, the nuclei appear optically clear and are referred to as ground-glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei. Nuclear pseudoinclusions, which occur due to inward invagination of the nuclear membrane, may also be seen. The characteristic nuclear features of PTC can be used to make the diagnosis even if the classic papillary architecture is not seen. Dystrophic calcification in the form of psammoma bodies are often seen in the core of the papillae. Lymphatic invasion may frequently be present, but the involvement of blood vessels is rare. 


PTC is associated with an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate of more than 95%.

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

  • Branching papillae 
  • Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk
  • Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes- 
    • Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusions
    • Nuclear grooves.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

Related Pearl: Follicular thyroid malignancy

It is more common in iodine-deficient areas. It is associated with p53, PTEN, PAX/PPAR-gamma, RAS, miRNA (miR-197 and miR-346).

It commonly presents as solitary thyroid nodules and the mean age of presentation is 50 years. It can also occur in long-standing cases of multinodular goitre.

FNAC is unable to distinguish between benign and malignant follicular lesions as malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion. Hence, Trucut biopsy is required to confirm malignancy.

Histological findings:

  • Encapsulated
  • Uniform microfollicles or sheets of cells devoid of colloid
  • Capsular and vascular invasion indicates malignancy
  • Tumour thrombus within middle thyroid/ jugular veins may be seen at the time of surgery

Vascular (hematogenous) dissemination is common, with metastases to bone, lungs, liver, and elsewhere. The prognosis depends largely on the extent of invasion and stage at presentation.

Serum thyroglobulin levels are used for monitoring tumour recurrence, as they are undetectable after complete treatment.
